text: On a windswept walk in Carmarthen... Make money work for you.
Come to your senses, British people... We are not bluffing.

We left the war game in the previous episode with the Russian president, played by Keir Giles, issuing an ultimatum... he demanded that the UK cease fire and withdraw all British forces to within sovereign territory.
This morning, we showed that the British cannot continue any longer to exercise their criminal activities against the Russian Federation.
But it's Russia that's been on the attack.
Oxford Circus have hit Oxford Circus.
Britain is reeling from two waves of deadly missile strikes... One launched at 3.15 in the morning, the other barely six hours later.
GCHQ destroyed. That is a massive issue for us, strategic issue for us.
The Royal Navy fought back.
We have sunk a Russian ship in self-defence. May I now sink that submarine I have under control?
Yes.
Now the British side, led by Sir Ben Wallace as Prime Minister, has been given an hour to respond to the Kremlin's ultimatum.
They've said they're not going to do any more waves... But if they engage, we will respond.
PM, the Russians are now, sorry, we've just got here, saying they're thanking the United States for their efforts to reach a ceasefire.
Lord Mark Sedwell as the National Security Advisor.

If in effect we're saying that we will also support those efforts... put the ball firmly into the American court if you're hoping that they will be able to enforce the ceasefire that they're talking about.
I think that's right. Can we craft a response in line with the NSA's recommendation?
Prime Minister, can I suggest that we give that as a statement to Parliament, having done one to the nation?
I think it would be a good moment to have it from behind the dispatch box... we are ready should they again take any action.
What you're listening to is the kind of war game that's genuinely tested inside government... Episode five, The Choice.
So we break, break, break, tea break. Is there a final phase?

With Russia having issued its ultimatum, and the British now agreed on their response, the players returned to the real world for another coffee break... Then, along a corridor and through two doors, is another big room where the Russia team is based.
With time ticking down on his pocket watch, Rob Johnson, the Gamesmaster, asks all the participants to retake their seats one last time.
So as we go into this final phase, try to get yourself in this mindset. We've just lost probably over 100 UK citizens.
Rob is also playing the chair of the Joint Intelligence Committee. He's addressing the main British room, where a final emergency COBRA meeting is about to start.
The cash numbers are going up. Londoners are bloody frightened. And the country is looking to us for national leadership right now.
In the war game, it's just gone midday... The Russian military chief, played by Tom Srostock, mistakenly thinks London is trying to trick Moscow into overplaying its hand.
I understand what they're doing. They want to have another attack by us and then the US would support them and allies would rally around.
He's saying this because the British side didn't agree to an unconditional ceasefire. They also made no mention of bringing home forces deployed overseas.
That's a political game that they could be playing... This could be a trap.
Yes, this could be a trap.
Maria Ankvest as the head of military intelligence.
And we should not exclude that they have already spoken to the Americans.
But if they do not agree to our ultimatum, then we must use further military force and that may play to their advantage, potentially.
But the UK isn't setting any traps... He comes to a decision.
We do have the justification for continuing on... A SoT set, an operation against the UK's critical national infrastructure with the aid of our subsea capabilities.
The latest update now on Russia's armed attack on the UK... It is currently unable to operate.
Can I just come in on the critical national infrastructure point?
We're in the smaller of the two British rooms where our team of experts is reacting to the latest attack... as well as hospitals, GPs and other public services.
We've lost gas power to half of the UK... It's 12 o'clock, so it's October, so it'll be dark in four and a half hours.
Professor Lucy Easthope is a leading authority on recovering from disaster... In the war game, her knowledge on how the public might be reacting and what they will need is vital.
We're kind of falling apart here at home.
You probably can't run the grid.
Sir Bernard Gray, a former top Ministry of Defence official,
So it's not our part of the ship, but if we can't run the gas stations, that's about 50% of in-store capacity... but broadly speaking, you can't run the whole grid.
What do you think it does, Bernard, to the industrial capacity to maintain sustainment of ammunition, weapons, fuel?
The Chief of Joint Operations, played by General Sir David Capewell,
Well, we can run some areas... So we could prioritise both military bases and Wharton and so forth.
Bernard Gray is referring to a defence industry site in Lancashire.
I turn off the Blackpool illuminations, but leave on Lytham St Anne's... So we could be out of civilian power for quite a long time.
As the experts react to the crisis, the Prime Minister and his team in the main Cobra Room must decide what move to take next. The Chancellor, played by Jim Murphy, is the first to speak.
The Prime Minister is clear now that the Russians are no longer just intent on harming our military capability, they intend, it would appear, to humble and destroy our economy and our way of life.
I think, first of all, we should work up some of the options... And we shouldn't forget that Russia's economy is less than half the Britain's economy.
Prime Minister, this is all for you to decide, of course... We run the risk of being perceived to be weak.
So I don't venture that... And while proportionately we've lost seven typhoons, we haven't lost seven pilots.
He's revealing the total number of British jets destroyed so far in the Russian missile strikes. These aircraft had been on the ground at their bases when the missiles came in.
We have been obviously damaged, but we have also avoided an escalation that we all know around this table we simply would not be able to maintain at the moment because of our weapon stocks.
We have very nuclear capability, Prime Minister.
I'm not going to go to nuclear war with Russia... And then we would be in a very difficult position.
Can I ask then, gently, Prime Minister, in the privacy of this room, that the Treasury has invested tens of billions of pounds in the nuclear deterrent.
It's also taken tens of billions of pounds out of the defense budget.
Our nation faces an existential crisis... And yet in this very moment, we are saying we are unwilling to travel up the escalatory ladder.
Chancellor, I really am surprised to hear you being so hawkish on this. That is the ultimate state.
Of course it is. And what does it take?
The deterrent worked... And once he'd made that decision, if that is his decision, it ended up putting confinement to his ambitions.
Prime Minister, he continues to attack us at this very moment.
The Russians have been attacking us for as long as the Treasury have been taking money out of our defence budget, Chancellor, since about 1991.
Prime Minister, we made those decisions jointly.
My Prime Minister will say to the Chancellor... would have engaged in the adventure that he has done for the last three years.
I think that's fair, Foreign Secretary... Because we haven't, we haven't, we haven't round this room discussed what our response to that should be.
And not just our economic capabilities... What circumstances would we use it Prime Minister?
Britain has one of the most forward-leaning policies on the nuclear deterrent... I think we have contained it.

The Home Secretary has left the Cobra meeting and walked across the corridor to the smaller British room... While the Prime Minister believes the nuclear deterrent has worked, this conflict isn't over.
Fortunately, we have an expert.
I heard a rumour. Thank you, Minister.
So to give you assurance straight away... We have activated that structure.
Now there could be a nuclear attack. What else can we do to alert the British public in a way that saves lives?... Let's face it, they're not used to that.
It is, and it's likely to cause some level of distress... and their contaminated casualties plan, and both of those are ready to go.
Thank you very much. I think I'll take that back to Cobra. Marvellous... Thank you very much.
I may well be back.
In the Russia Room, before going back into character, the red team is deciding how best to talk about the secretive part of the Russian military that just carried out the pipeline attack.
Our main directorate for Deepwater Research, or as we call it in Russian, Glavnoye Pravleny, etc., etc.
Glavnoye Pravleny and Gubakavodnyk Islyadovany, or GUGY... It's under Chief of General Staff Command.
I mean, deep-sea research director, that does sound like, you know, Glasgow School of Marine Biology.
Robin Hagblom, who's playing the commander of Russia's Northern Fleet, is suggesting a better way to describe it.
Something like our deep-sea special forces.
That's a good phrase. Yes, deep-sea special forces.
The Russia team then step back into their roles. And they're sounding pretty pleased with themselves.
Mr President, for many years we have been mapping the Western undersea infrastructure... Our efforts have really paid off.
Is there any reason to change our earlier assessment of how the United Kingdom... Chief of Military Intelligence, to you first please.
I do not see any reason... by responding they risk more severe consequences and potentially a nuclear confrontation with a major nuclear power.
Yes, they should realize that it is not the time to escalate... and can handle them with great care.
Thank you. So at this point we remain confident that our operation may achieve its objectives and be successful?
Yes, Mr President. Thank you.

The Russia side hit the gas pipeline as it hadn't been satisfied with the British response to its ultimatum... Their removal would leave a country that was once part of the Soviet Union looking very exposed.

As the commander of the Northern Fleet, I do have a slight worry... But on the other hand, give them a little time during ceasefire negotiations or similar, and we might face a very different situation.
So if they regenerate their capacity for defense... things will be harder in the future to reinforce the message?
Yes. So we should press home the advantage now as long as we have it.
Understood. In that case, please draw up further contingency plans... Thank you, Admiral.
But the Russians aren't the only ones making plans.
Amazon offers term time working... conditions apply.
I've always been ambitious... How many other professions can say that?
Every lesson shapes a life... Search Get Into Teaching.

The UK Defence Chief, played by General Sir Richard Barons, has also decided to visit the smaller British room... He also wants ideas from the Chief of Joint Operations for what the Prime Minister has called strategic dilemmas to exert pressure on Russia.

It has become clear that given the shortage of our conventional options, if we get pushed so far, we're only left with a strategic nuclear deterrent... Primaris is quite clear he wants some options developed.

The defence chief asks again about an F-35 bombing raid inside Russia. He also repeats the prime minister's suggestion of sending troops to Russia's border with Norway or Finland to potentially attack a Russian naval base.

Insofar as a deep strike into Russia by F-35s is concerned... And so what we will do is think of other solutions that might give us an answer to the making sure we can reach into the heart of the Russian system.
The Chief of Joint Operations touches again on a question he raised at the very start of the crisis about how to end the fight. He knows he also needs to be ready for further attacks.

As far as I'm concerned, most of the options that remain concern conflict termination, which still leaves at risk the optionality of escalating to a nuclear response of some sort, including a demonstration.
I think that's right. If we go back to the beginning of this... So we should press on all points. But we are extremely vulnerable.

The Defence Chief leaves the room and the Chief of Joint Operations turns to his advisors... even though it's the RAF's most expensive and sophisticated warplane fitted with technology to evade enemy air defences.
Any discussion over the F-35 right now needs to reckon with its current weapons fit... Exactly.
A bomb needs to be dropped on a target rather than fired from a distance, raising the risk of the jet being shot down.

So you are flying to the equivalent point blank range with your F-35 to drop a bomb on a target... And you are therefore placing all of your eggs in the basket of we can evade all of their air defenses.

Still risky but with a higher chance of success, the RAF could use its other fighter jet, the Typhoon, that can fire cruise missiles from a distance. But these older aircraft lack the radar evading technology of the F-35.
You would want to be launching outside over at the very edge of the air engagement zone for their air defense missiles... Bearing in mind, TLAMs get intercepted.
TLAM stands for Tomahawk Land Attack Missile.

They are a subsonic missile and Russian air defence is probably capable of taking some of them out on the way in, so you'd have to be imaginative about how you launch those in or accompany it with something that's firing decoys.

The team is also against the Prime Minister's suggestion of deploying 16 Air Assault Brigade to Russia's northern border because it doesn't have enough air defence systems to protect itself... But in the real world, the only two warships in the Royal Navy designed for beach landings are being sold off to Brazil.
So the team improvises.
Are you even considering the carrier around the top to go and do?... Royal. Royal Marines.
Tom Sharp, the former Royal Navy officer, is suggesting sending Royal Marines on an aircraft carrier. Special Forces, or SF, would also be on board.
What, as an SF insertion device? 65,000 tonne SF insertion device?
Having unfortunately sold off some months previously to Brazil the two landing platforms.
The Chief of Joint Operations then receives an inject of information from Rob Johnson as the Games Master... But would London do the same?
Like all politicians, they want an a la carte menu, and we don't think like that... In fact, it's wasteful and probably self-harming if it has no object.

I do think with all of this, one of the ways to take the public with you is going to have to be what comes after this... and This would be a chance to look like we have tried to behave very ethically and within the rules of engagement.
Yeah, how much of a sour taste does it all leave?
Wanting the fighting to stop, the US Secretary of State has sent a message to the Russian president. He condemns the gas pipeline attack and demands a ceasefire.

Message from the United States. We would hope that there would be no more military action by either side... I shall thank the United States for their leadership, because no other president of the United States could have done this.
No. They have been very generous. Of course, they realize that that is in their best interest.
Yes, but pursuing an even-handed approach should still be appreciated. We believe that the current United States President is someone we can work with.
Indeed.
The team then receives its first message from the American leader.
We have a message from the President of the United States via Secretary of State. POTUS is committed to peace in Europe and believes that constructive engagement with Russia is vital for that end.
Colleagues, I believe we have won.
We have indeed. This is a great success for us.
Just need to wait for the other side to realize that.

The Russians have reached this conclusion because the United States has still not rallied behind the UK... They believe it means Britain will have no choice but to comply with all of their ceasefire demands.
In the British room though, the Prime Minister and his team have not admitted defeat... He still sounds in favour of deploying F-35 jets.
We're examining conventional deep strike using the F-35 into Russia... CGO is telling me if we go for a ground-based Murmansk option, we should expect a minimum of 50% good casualties.
We need to explore what the Norwegians will do... We will continue to pursue with our allies and like-minded friends the Russian threat until that is dissipated.
That's of course what the British side wants... Every country has its secrets, and it's at this moment the National Security Advisor has the last word.
PM, can I just remind colleagues of something the Prime Minister said about half an hour ago... Good.
Thank you, sir. Done. Very, very, very, very much indeed. We are End Ex, as they used to say in the armed forces.
We'll probably be listened to by the Russian military academy in the next five years.

The war game ends less than 10 hours after the first missiles were launched... But if the UK and its allies did fight back, with or without the United States, this could mark the beginning of a much wider war.
I sometimes wonder if the Prime Minister understands that he would have to preemptively use nuclear weapons if it became known that the Russians were going to launch a ballistic missile at Fazlai.
I'm back at Chris Donnelly's house... What Chris is saying is that he thinks a real government would not only go nuclear, but would launch the strike before the missiles had even landed.
It wouldn't be a tripwire response... If we risk something which destroys our capacity to react, we have to shoot first.

In the Cold War, because the UK and its European allies had larger conventional forces, they had more options to deter threats conventionally rather than a rapid escalation to using weapons of mass destruction.
As our conventional armed forces have shrunk... So we have to use it first.
And do you think that's understood?
I don't know. I doubt it.
How dangerous is it to have lost that conventional deterrent ramp?
It makes the risk of error catastrophic instead of just serious.
In the war game, Ben Wallace said Britain's nuclear deterrent had worked... We ran the game a couple of months before this.
The real British government published a major review of defence in early June.
The document confirms the hollowed-out state of the armed forces, but also what needs to be done to rebuild them.
and we prevent wars by being strong enough to fight and win them.
Unusually, the review was led by a team of external experts, including General Sir Richard Barons, the defence chief in our war game.

When we went through the Wargame experience we had already completed drafting the review... in that it identifies we live in a really difficult world of potential for state confrontation and conflict.
The review places NATO at the heart of UK defence policy, trusting in the Alliance's pledge of collective defence... but the review contains very little on how to fix them.

Within the frame of the defence review, there was really never any credible question of affording something that people might call the UK Iron Dome... big shout from civil society to want to find that money at the expense of something else before I think it becomes an early prospect.
What sort of money?
So I hesitate to quote sums of money but as a rule of thumb entry-level ability to shoot down incoming missiles from ground-based interceptors entry-level about 25 billion pounds.
Lots of other holes are addressed though... But this change will be expensive and require all of society to play a part.

We should look at Ukraine and remind ourselves that we're having an argument about whether we spend three or three and a half percent or four percent of GDP on deterrence... And with that war will come massive destruction, and the war game has illustrated that.
The Defense Review describes Russia as an immediate and pressing threat... Vladimir Putin's ambassador to the UK was also interviewed on Sky News.
Based on the defence review here in this country, one of the major threats they see is from Russia.
Yeah, it is fantastic and I like it... What does he mean?
As you know, the UK chose to shrink its defences when the Cold War ended, believing that Moscow no longer posed a threat... Whether or not we fix them, well, that's the big choice.

identified_role: Director, Changing Character of War Centre
text: I've got to get myself back in there.
So, shall I just ask a couple of questions? Yeah, go ahead. Okay, so I am with Rob after the game. So, how did you think it went?

identified_role: Director, Changing Character of War Centre
text: I think it went better than I expected... And I think it's a simple reason they really care.
In the game, it stops really in the middle of the crisis. How does this end?

identified_role: Director, Changing Character of War Centre
text: Well, in designing the game, we want to leave it with a sort of cliffhanger moment where the listener themselves can decide, do I feel safe?... This is a game that doesn't have a definitive ending, because this is a game that the public will finish.
The War Game was written and presented by me, Deborah Haynes... and the executive producers were Sarah Whitehead and David Mapstone.
This year, Amazon are increasing the electric delivery vehicles we use across Europe to 10,000... Delivery service partner vehicles across the UK and EU.
